reason: For sequential collections, aggregate degenerates to foldLeft. The combining operation for parallel collections is unused. Therefore, it is recommended to prefer foldLeft for sequential collections.

reason: Use `++=` aka `addAll` instead of varargs `+=`; infix operations with an operand of multiple args will be deprecated

Infix operations with an operand of multiple args will be deprecated. The intention is to encourage use of the clearer and more explicit `addAll` method instead of varargs `+=` in order to maintain consistency and readability.

This method should no longer be overridden or called. It was originally expected that prepare would be called by all libraries that consume ExecutionContexts, in order to capture thread local context. However, this usage has proven difficult to implement in practice and instead it is now better to avoid using prepare entirely. Instead, if an ExecutionContext needs to capture thread local context, it should capture that context when it is constructed, so that it doesn't need any additional preparation later.

The recommended implementation of prepare is to return this. This method should no longer be overridden or called. It was originally expected that prepare would be called by all libraries that consume ExecutionContexts, in order to capture thread local context. However, this usage has proven difficult to implement in practice and instead it is now better to avoid using prepare entirely. Instead, if an ExecutionContext needs to capture thread local context, it should capture that context when it is constructed, so that it doesn't need any additional preparation later.

reason: Deprecated since version 2.10.0. Use scala.reflect.ClassTag instead.

The functionality of `AnyValManifest` was largely subsumed by `TypeTag`, which offers more robust subtype checking capabilities and aligns better with the Scala compiler improvements. The previous API was deemed limiting and redundant.
ClassTag is a weaker special case of scala.reflect.api.TypeTags.TypeTag, in that they wrap only the runtime class of a given type, whereas a TypeTag contains all static type information.

examples.code: scala> def mkArray[T : ClassTag](elems: T*) = Array[T](elems: _*)mkArray: [T](elems: T*)(implicit evidence$1: scala.reflect.ClassTag[T])Array[T]scala> mkArray(42, 13)res0: Array[Int] = Array(42, 13)scala> mkArray("Japan","Brazil","Germany")res1: Array[String] = Array(Japan, Brazil, Germany)

reason: Deprecated since version 2.10.0, use scala.reflect.runtime.universe.TypeTag for subtype checking instead.

examples.code:
def arr[T] = new Array[T](0)                          // does not compile
def arr[T](implicit m: Manifest[T]) = new Array[T](0) // compiles
def arr[T: Manifest] = new Array[T](0)                // shorthand for the preceding
// Methods manifest and optManifest are in [[scala.Predef]].
def isApproxSubType[T: Manifest, U: Manifest] = manifest[T] <:< manifest[U]
isApproxSubType[List[String], List[AnyRef]] // true
isApproxSubType[List[String], List[Int]]    // false
def methods[T: Manifest] = manifest[T].runtimeClass.getMethods
def retType[T: Manifest](name: String) = methods[T] find (_.getName == name) map (_.getGenericReturnType)
retType[Map[_, _]]("values")  // Some(scala.collection.Iterable<B>)

reason: The `between` method was deprecated due to potential misuse and unclear behavior when specifying ranges. The new method `nextInclusiveBetween` provides better clarity and enforces inclusivity at both bounds to mitigate errors.

In Scala 3, the DelayedInit feature was dropped. App exists only in a limited form that also does not support command line arguments and will be deprecated in the future. @main methods are the recommended scheme to generate programs that can be invoked from the command line in Scala 3.
DelayedInit semantics can be surprising. Support for `App` will continue.
Implicit conversion from Long to Double is dangerous because it loses precision. Write `.toDouble` instead.
Implicit conversion from Int to Float is dangerous because it loses precision.
